comments.commentBody:
"despite crippling sanctions" -- We have not seen anything that fairly qualifies for that term, and it is not clear we ever would. That would be up to the EU, and be economic suicide for the EU, a major recession at the least.

Meanwhile, the Russians have escalation dominance. The EU has quite openly said they will not do a land war with Russia -- even the PM of Britain just said so in as many words.

It is time to manage this more and hyperventilate less.

Mike, what would you say if Great Britain decided to put the "legitimate pieces of their nation back together again", and launched a military offensive against the east coast of the U.S.? Who cares about what was in the past? Today, now, Ukraine is a sovereign nation of proud Ukrainians who are loyal to their flag of yellow and blue, NOT the white, blue and red of Russia. Go to Ukraine and talk to Ukrainians before jumping to any conclusions.

I believe it's too late for that.

Russia is not quite as fearful as one might think; they know western interference will not occur, and the sanctions will not be meaningful or long lived.

They are fully intent on rebuilding their influence; the Crimea and Ukraine are the first steps in this expansion.

In fact, I'm inclined to believe the west may have already agreed to certain Russian moves, and the saber rattling is just for show.

Ukraine has already played Putin's "ceasefire" game, remember? A seven-day ceasefire in June that was extended three more days. All that ceasefire did was to give Putin the opportunity to strengthen the hand of the seasoned Russian operatives he sent in to take eastern Ukraine in the same cowardly and dastardly way he took Crimea.

Ukraine has had enough of Putin's games, and the rest of the world is finally coming around as well. It is horrible that it took the downing of a civilian aircraft, the loss of nearly 300 people - and the disgusting response by Putin's "rebels" - for this to happen.

Ah, Randy, so Iraq and Afghanistan were demonstrations of our ability to "assert some influence in foreign lands...."? And, just how many body bags and maimed soldiers and lives of innocent civilians do you need to satisfy yourself that we are "respected and feared"? 100? 1,000? 10,000?

Do you miss Viet Nam? We had a great deal of influence there, including toppling governments. Over 58,000 U.S. soldiers and over 800,000 South Vietnamese died in a place that tourists go to on vacation today.

So much for asserting influence in foreign lands.

You do realize that the Baltic states are all post-Soviet states experiencing negative population growth. Moreover, Latvia and Estonia actually have a portion of ethnic Russians that is now higher than present day Ukraine (meaning without Crimea).  The fate of the Baltics is very much riding on the fate of Ukraine.

Continuing: Russia hs always been wanted. It is a rich country. It can produce lots of food and enough food for all the inhabitants and much more. It is due to the politics of Jeltsin and Gorbatchov that it imports chickens from the United States. There is no need to do this. Therefore I am glad with these sanctions. Russia will have to produce food itself. It is also rich concerning minerals, gold, etc. Everyone knows this. It is also rich be course the population is well educated. In  Holland only 10 – 15 % has had Academic schooling (I don't know how you call this in English). In Russia 40 – 50 % visited university. Yesterday I read a statement from a Russian guy who is studying in Delft. He said that in Russia this kind of technical school is better. You have to learn more, but Holland and Delft are better in Public Relations. Therefore he came to Delft. Another guy I know is studying engeneering spacecraft. His professor told him to do his training in India or in Russia, not in the United States. (please also read my former comment and my next)

NATO will never fire a shot to defend the Baltic States, thank God!  And I'm Latvian. NATO is a joke thanks to Germany, France, Denmark, Netherlands, etc. always hiding behind America's military might and not paying a dime for it!

Soon Russia invades and takes "New Russia". Probably incrementally he drives as far as Odessa. Then they hook up with Transnistria, They have conquered much corrupt, impoverished territory with negative population growth. much like Mother Russia. Together with Belarus as a proxy state, Putin will have reinvented part of USSR. But USSR was an highly unsuccessful venture, so Putin may enjoy some regional glory in his lifetime, but in the long run, things will be grim for that region.

The Baltic States are a different matter. US and NATO would stand up for them. I hope.

Here is an explanation of the conclusion from LAN, by examining the situation from the perspectives of each child:

The first child chooses the K options which he most prefers (preference numbers 1, 2, … K). The second child chooses one of these options. So on average, the second child’s choice will have preference number $(K+1)/2$ to the first child.

The second child receives the K options from the first child. To the second child, his most preferred of these K options will on average have preference number $(N+1)/(K+1)$. This is because choosing K options out of an ordered list of N possibilities is equivalent to partitioning a list of $(N-K)$ options into $(K+1)$ subgroups, with each subgroup having on average $(N-K)/(K+1)$ elements. The second child’s best choice will therefore have preference number 1 + $(N-K)/(K+1)$ = $(N+1)/(K+1)$ to him on average.

The fair situation arises when $(K+1)/2$ = $(N+1)/(K+1)$, as LAN asserts.
This is quite a cynical post, Mr. McTeague. You seem to be presenting the argument that all employers today are abusers of young people simple due to greed. Do you really believe this?
Makes me feel rather good as an alumnus to read of Columbia College students sharing some of the wonder of that mind expanding Core Curriculum experience with those less privileged younger people.

They say that youth is wasted on the young. I think it's maturity that's frittered away. Squandered on the insatiable pursuit of material acquisition, on the obstinacy of our beliefs, on wariness and distrust, on building ever more barricades to understanding and acceptance.

We can learn a lot from these kids, open-minded to all viewpoints, college students selflessly helping high school students, all for the sheer joy of learning and bettering our world, protecting it from, as one savvy participant put it, the "innate thirst for total power."

These are the kinds of programs corporate America should be embracing, to cultivate future growth and prosperity, rather than treating the young as just more vulnerable prey they can dupe and disenfranchise to make a quick financial killing.

Thank you, Mr. Bruni, for a breath of fresh air in a fetid climate of self-interest.

My mind goes a bit off the scale at times.  But I wonder if Putin isn't underhandedly trying to reel the US into another debacle?  The military contractor bunch will cry 'foul', we need to DO something.  Our better Angels tell us, let this sort itself out.  We have sacrificed so much of our treasure and finances, that we need to step back and let this sort itself out.  Europe has a stake in this.  Where are they?  The last thing we need is yet another intervention into the conflict in the mid east and Ukraine.  This is their sons and daughters and finances to sacrifice.  We have done this before, and if we have not learned the lesson of "if you always do what you always did, you always get what you always got".  Our military is stretched thin, we cannot care for our Veterans as it is.  How could we possibly ask for more?

Why did your mom marry your father? And why did she stay with him? Why didn't her mother help her with your father? Obviously we need our high schools to help young girls learn how to stop these abuses and make better choices in husbands.
Which should bring us to the question as to why this woman married Rice? Can someone provide some common sense as to why this marriage took place?

When World War I broke out, the nations of Europe joined the battle because, "It was a matter of honor." As we commemorate the 100 year anniversary of WWI, it looks like Putin has his own WWI celebration under way. Instead of a reenactment, he is about to launch an invasion of Ukraine for what? Honor?

Are the Russian Ukrainians so different from the Ukrainian Russians that they can't get along? They used too. What happened? Has honor once again started a major war?

Some are commenting that the US is perceived as weak, so wars are breaking out all over the world as well as in Ukraine. Nuts! We can't keep people from killing each other. We can, actually, but we would have to kill about 100 times as many to keep the killers from doing their killing. It's not worth escalating the violence for the sake of our honor.

The eastern sections of Ukraine are not worth starting WWIII. Putin will do what he wants. He doesn't care about economic sanctions. It's the honor thing again.

Recall that we invaded Iraq and look how that turned out. Did the rest of the world levy economic sanctions against us? No. It wasn't worth it. Neither is this.

Libya, Syria, Mali, Somalia, Iraq and many other areas have fallen in spite of our efforts. That doesn't mean we are weak or have no honor. It means the world is a dangerous place and we can't do anything about it. Putin will take eastern Ukraine in spit of our honor and in glorification of his.
The miscalculation: It is not becoming. It has been forever

JL,

You may believe further sanctions will occur, and indeed there are several that would hurt the Russian economy, but not for long.

America is not going to war over this, nor is Europe.

The die is cast. The Ukraine may not yet understand it, but their destiny is already decided. Together with Crimea, the are the first states of the revitalized Russian Federation.

The cities of Donetsk and Luhansk are surrounded and forces are entering Donetsk right now. The insurgents footprint of territory is shrinking by the day. The insurgents cannot travel between the 2 cities as the Ukrainian Army has control of the roads between them. This reduces ability to reinforce or to resupply various units.

https://twitter.com/NSDC_ua/status/496234843337158656/photo/1
Perhaps the fact that they have cut the rebel held territory down to 1/3 of its starting scale after the Russian mercenaries entered in May.  This is usually a definition of winning.
Nevertheless Stalingrad resisted and broke the Germans

Ukraine today says up to 30,000 Russian Federation troops on the Ukrainian border. Remember that Putin had the Duma revoke his authorization for military action in Ukraine but that could be re-instated in a day.

The Ukrainian Army is within winning against the Insurgents as their territory dwindles and are cut off from reinforcements and supplies.

Russia has used the "peacekeeping forces" ruse before in Moldova and Georgia. The only thing that may stop Putin is a reiteration of the severity of sanctions he would certainly face. Nonetheless, the chances of an invasion seem to be quite high within the next week.

"The total number of battle groups in the adjacent Ukrainian territory up to 33 thousand troops of the Russian Federation, the deputy secretary of the NSDC Michael Koval.

"Near the boundaries of Ukraine is up to 33 thousand members of the Armed Forces and up to 160 tanks," - said M.Koval Monday night in the program "Freedom of Speech" on TV ICTV, responding to a question.

Interfax-Ukraine"

the French had some very good weapons. (the French 75 artillery gun) Both sides had Commanders that didn't know how to work with their new war toys.
Anyone who calls the French 'surrender monkeys' or something like it is just showing their ignorance. Someday I want to Visit Verdun and some of the trench museums. It's time to watch Kirk Douglas as Col. Dax in "Paths of Glory " again.

They are moving to the autocratic capitalism pioneered by Singapore and adopted with huge success (so far) by China.

The success of that model is clear, in growth rates nothing else matches, and in moving the broad population out of poverty, and in enriching the elite at the same time.

The support for this comes without the military domination and IMF strings of Western support for its much lower growth model.

There is reason to doubt this will keep working for China, much less that it can be translated into African cultures. But there is no reasonable doubt that is where things are going.

The rest is whistling past the graveyard. The West is not going to get back into those economies.

It is a historical fact that Islam invaded India, and so did Christianity (through the colonising effort of the British). However, neither had the success that they achieved in other parts of the world. The various civilisations like the Greek, the Roman, the Mesopotamian, the Aztecs, etc., were completely destroyed, when their lands were physically captured. The Hindus fought the invaders at the physical level where they could. But, more importantly, they fought back at the intellectual level. So, when India became independent in 1947, the Hindu civilisation was still alive, and so it has become part of the consciousness.

Wherever they went, the invaders succeeded because of the excessive force that was used against the indigenous people. Like in the case of the Americas, there was near extermination. In other cases, the defeated people converted to the religion of the invaders. Hindu civilisation is an exception.

You mention" unintended pregnancies and with some of the solutions being birth control and abortion which are being increasingly restricted".  Like many, you advocate treating the symptom, but not the disease.  The disease is a culture of not being responsible for one's actions, lack of commitment to a marriage, or to raising a child (born in or out of wedlock) to adulthood.  This is why 50% of our children are now raised by a single parent.  Hold people accountable for their actions and things will improve.

Actually, that's not true.  At least not the way you've represented it.  Birth rates amonst teenage women have been declining for a decade.  We do NOT have a higher unintended rate than the world (the world encompasses women that have no right to not get pregnant, according to law or religious belief).  And the western nations have a negative birth rate as they no longer get married and most (the majority) do not want to have kids.  Of course, we do pay women to have babies in the US through ill-concieved laws that pay you for each unwanted baby you have as long as their is no father living in the same home.  So we do have that - unintended, yet intended.

Perhaps a minor edit will help: hold WOMEN responsible for everybody's actions, and make sure we do nothing about their poverty, lack of jobs and education, lousy child care, unequal pay, exposure to male violence, and general unequal treatment.

One suspects that Marx had a point, in comparing women to working class and poor people: the more "responsibility," is larded upon them, the less likely they are to get together and fight for better.

Into the bargain, sticking it to poor women especially helps warn luckier women to stay in line.

Almost half (49%) of U.S. pregnancies are unintended, more than 3 million unintended pregnancies per year. The United States rate of unintended pregnancies is higher than the world average, and much higher than that in other industrialized nations (according to facts/research reported in Wikipedia). With affordable and safe access to birth control, abortion, and family planning/health resources becoming increasingly restricted state by state -- it's mind boggling to see such regressive policies. When I'm not angry, I weep.

I think it does the opposite. This current obsession with our pets is another sign of our growing misanthropy and intolerance for complex human relationships. There's a false innocence and a creation of false identity that we project onto animals, that we can't easily do with people we know. We do this with children until they grow up, express their voices, and obliterate the fantasies we have about them.

We have a level of control over animals that we don't have over free human beings who make their own choices and have opinions that we have no sway over. We don't embrace animals because we are more humanized. Animals have always been easy to embrace. Even the worst among us can love puppies. We feel for animals because it's hard to feel for humans. We're unwilling to embrace true individuality and opinions that oppose our own. Until then, animals are this "feel-good about yourself" substitute for our growing intolerance for the world you can't control.

Your reasoning isn't supported by the data. The US greatly exceeds all other countries in the world in performing back surgeries and we don't get any better outcomes to show for it. We do so many of these procedures mainly because orthopedic surgery is a highly paid specialty in the US and so we've end up with a lot of orthopedic surgeons. In a fee for service system like we have, surgeons can create demand for their services by doing procedures for conditions for which they are not really indicated. In many cases, the outcomes for surgery a roughly even mix of some getting better, some staying the same, and some getting worse.

I would appreciate it if you went with the gender neutral form of the term. From now on please say “straw figure” instead of “straw man”.

Thank you.
Just think of the profits manufacturing all of those plastic water bottles. It's not their problem to dispose them.

For one example Nestle' takes from local water sources here in Calif to sell at a profit the water that belongs to us all. Why buy bottled tap water when you can fill & refill a recyclable bottle and avoid all the waste, pollution and exploitation from big corporations who have questionable reputations.

It’s really OK, isn’t it, members of Congress, if your constituents lose access to local sources of water. If they do, your wonderful contributors like Pepsi, Coke and Nestle can make lots more money selling bottled water, and contribute so much more to your important campaigns!
A little less beef? How about none at all?
Women are more than half the population, so it is a huge thing. Give it some thought. Thanks.

And I would go one step further in saying that there is a large and vocal contingent in the "trans woman" community which is politically anti-female and vociferously misogynistic.  When a guy in a dress tells me that he knows better than I do -- who has been female for 56 years -- what it's like to be a "woman," I wonder about how "cis" I am and how "cis" he is.
